Peter Jonathan is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs, and also feed for the fish. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Peter Jonathan from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business and support his family financially.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs, and also feed for the fish.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian G. has been dedicated, since she was very young, to working in a hog fattening business. Presently, Vivian relies on this activity to cover her personal costs and help sustain her family. Vivian buys piglets from her neighbors, raises them, and when they have reached a good point of development, she sells them to business people who visit the village. This activity is very common in their area, and many entrepreneurs do this.

As a busy entrepreneur, Vivian has also provided for her family by operating a sari-sari (variety) store. Sari-sari stores basically sell small quantities of various foodstuffs, grocery items, and beverages. “Sari” is a native word for variety. This is a small store that is either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage not far away from the owner’s house. Such stores are convenient for people in the village who live far from the marketplace.

Vivian wishes to expand her businesses by buying more piglets, vitamins, and feed for piglets, and support the needs of her store, in order to forge ahead with her businesses and be able to help her family get ahead. For this reason, she is for the first time approaching Kiva for a loan through ASHI amounting of 49,000 Php to help her reach her goal.

Vivian is a hard working woman dedicated to her home. Her dream is to care for her two children and offer them a better quality of life. Vivian’s neighbors, friends, and even her group mates consider her a respectful person.

Her dreams are to provide a better future for her family, sustain the profitability of her business, and start a savings account for her children and support them to finish studies until complete college and find good jobs. Through hard work and determination, Vivian is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives and support from ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more piglets, vitamins, and feed for piglets, and support the needs of her store.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra S. is from the town of Banga. She is 48 years old. Sandra is married and has 4 children. Her eldest is aged 28 and the youngest is 20. To make a living, Sandra owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Sandra wishes for her children to become professionals some day.

Sandra joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sandra has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Sandra is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Uiimdas

texts.en: Uiimdas K. is 57 years old and lives with his wife in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his wife have been living in their current home for the past 30 years. Their children are now grown and live separately. Uiimdas operates a taxi service in his local area, using his own car to transport people to and from points in his province. He became a driver in 1976, working in a government agency until 1989. He is a modest and hardworking man. His daughter-in-law runs a small food cafe. Uiimdas says, "I want to build a big restaurant for my son". As his car is now beginning to age, Uiimdas hopes to soon make some needed repairs. He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase new tires and repair his car.

loans.use: To purchase new tires and repair his car

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante D. is from the town of Banga. He is 27 years old and single. To make a living, Dante raises pigs for fattening and sale and working on his farm where he plants and harvests rice. He says he is saving for his future as he dreams to have his own family someday.

Dante joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and farm supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Dante from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Annaliza

texts.en:
Annaliza G. is from the town of Banga. She is 33 years old and single with a 9-year-old child. Annaliza's main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also manages a sari-sari store where she sells various products. She hopes to grow her store.

Annaliza joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Annaliza from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Urnuhbileg

texts.en: Urnuhbileg G.  is 32 years old and lives with her big family in Hovd province in western Mongolia. Her family enjoys a comfortable lifestyle and they all are in good health. Her elder two children attend a local middle school, the middle son goes to a kindergarten, the youngest one is too little and stays at home under the care of her mother. Her husband works as a security guard for a local security company. She and her family has lived in the province for 6 years. Urnuhbileg operates a taxi service in her area. Since starting in 2008, she has made much progress with her business which has improved her family's life. She is optimistic about her future and hopes to work with her husband to expand her transportation business to an adjoining province. Urnuhbileg is an open-minded and kind woman who remains optimistic about achieving her goals. She is requesting a 2,800,000 MNT loan to purchase a motor, tires, and other parts for her transport car.

loans.use: To purchase a motor, tires and other car parts

loans.name: Ashirhan's Group

texts.en:
Ashirhan T., leader of the group, is 54 and a widow. She has three sons — 33, 26, and 21. All her children are builders. Ashirhan is a pensioner and also breeds cattle which she started after her marriage because her husband’s parents left them cattle. She has almost twenty years experience in cattle breeding. Monthly, she gets 1000 soms. Her sons help her. She is applying for a loan in order to buy construction materials to make repairs at her house and to buy a calf to fatten and resell at a higher price. In the future, she is planning to make capital repairs on her house and arrange to marry her sons. 

Group members: 
Mahabathon A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 35 and divorced with three children. Her elder son is 25, her second son is 17 and her daughter is 15. Her elder son is a builder, her second son works in agriculture, and her daughter is at school and receives maintenance of two thousand soms. Mahabathon breeds cattle with the help of her children and sells milk in the mornings. She also makes 250 soms per day working for others. She started cattle breeding with an initial investment of 6500 soms and with the profits she bought a milk cow. Now, she makes 1500 soms a month. She is applying for a loan to buy another cow and school supplies for her children. In the future, on the profits from cattle breeding, she is planning to make capital repairs on her house and marry her sons.

Muhabbat A. is 44 and married. Her husband is a worker who receives 2000 soms per month. She has five children. Her sons are 22, 15, and 13 years old; her daughters are 17 and 10. Her elder son works in Kazakhstan, her elder daughter helps take care of their house, and her other children go to school. Mahabbat has five milk cows and sells from eight to ten liters of milk a day. She also breeds cattle. Fifteen years ago, she started her business with an initial investment of 10 000 soms and increased her livestock to nine cows, ten sheep, twenty goats, and one horse.  Monthly she gets 2500 soms. She is applying for a loan to buy more sheep to fatten and resell to make profits. On the profits from her business, Muhabbaton is planning to build a house and give her children higher education.

Dilaramhan M. is 36 and married. She has four children: her daughters are 17, 15 and 9; her son is 12. Her elder daughters are in Russia and her other children go to school. Her husband works in Russia. Eight years ago, she started cattle breeding. Now, her son in his free time, helps her. She started with an initial investment of 6500 soms and she now makes 2000 soms monthly. She is applying for a loan to buy a bull for fattening. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy construction materials and a calf

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en:
Rosanna J. is from the town of Banga. She is 38 years old and married with three school-aged children. Rosanna is a farmer and helps her husband plant and harvest rice crops. She also plants fruit trees like "rambutan," a kind of lychee. She also makes food that she sells in the community. Like other mothers, she wants to see her children be professionals someday.

Rosanna joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer. She will also buy ingredients for cooking. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Rosanna from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and ingredients for cooking the food she sells

loans.name: Erdenebaatar

texts.en:
Erdenebaatar M. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family have been living together in the same apartment where the children were raised for the past thirteen  years. His wife used to work as a tailor and then she started to run her own sewing business. His two daughters both attend a local secondary school in Ulaanbaatar. 

Since 1995, they have started several businesses, such as sewing, a bath house and a sauna. They used to operate their businesses in a rented basement of an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, but due to high rental prices they started running their businesses at their home. 

Erdenebaatar recently expanded his businesses by hiring a new hairdresser. In the future he hopes to grow his business by adding a new laundry service. Besides his businesses, he works at Atmor company as a water equipment installer. Erdenebaatar works very hard and is a clever man.  

He is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to make a renovation at his bath house.

loans.use: To make a renovation at his bath house.

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn Sta. M., 46 years of age, is married to a farmer, Vicente Sta. M.. They were blessed with two sons and one daughter. Emelyn joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), Rizal Central Branch, a partner Microfinance Institution of KIVA, in the year 1998. She decided to S. with the lending institution because she had found fulfillment being a member. She is proud because ASHI is part of the achievements of her eldest son and daughter who are now degree holders. Their eldest works now as a seaman, and her daughter just graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics. Her youngest son is still in college. Their primary source of income is farming and secondary is the tricycle which her husband drive for passenger purposes. 

Again she is applying for a loan to buy cattle for her husband to use in tilling their farm land. With the help of these cattle, expenses on rentals for tractors/machinery to plow their land will be reduced. The couple projects to increase their profit and wants to develop their farming method. Their future plan is to increase rice production and buy additional livestock, not just for the future of their family, but they want to provide employment to their community too and help other families as well. They are hoping that ASHI and KIVA will continue their partnership in helping them meet their goals in life and also providing capital and encouraging poor but enterprising families to rise from poverty.

loans.use: Cattles to use in cultivating their farmland

loans.name: Ainagul's Group

texts.en:
Ainagul S., leader of the group, is 26 and married. She has two children: her son is four years old and daughter is one year old. Her husband works in Russia. Before her marriage, the women in her husband’s family were selling clothes. After marriage, Ainagul decided to continue her husband’s family business. Now, she is already one year in such business. She started it with initial investment of 5000 soms. Now, her monthly income is 6000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to increase turnover. On the received loan, she is planning to buy pajamas, jackets, trousers, and female and male underwear to resell. On the profits from her business, she wants to buy a car for her family.

Group members:

Aiymkan E. is treasurer of the group. She is 27 and married. She has two children, five and two years old. Her husband is a taxi driver. With the help of her husband, Aiymkan breeds cattle. In 2004, they decided to hold money in cattle because they considered it safer. They bought two additional livestock for 6000 soms. In six years, they increased number of cattle to seven. Now, cattle breeding bring 3000 soms monthly. They are applying for a loan in order to buy livestock. Then, they will fatten and resell livestock at a higher price. 

Gulmira B. is 32 and married. She has three sons. The elder son is nine, her second son is eight, and they go to school. Her third son is four and he is at home. Her husband is carpenter. Gulimira breeds cattle. She started cattle breeding when she and he husband decided to buy a cow in order to have milk for everyday. Now, she has a cow and a calf and six cattle. Starting cattle breeding with initial investment of 10,000 soms, Gulmira makes 3000 soms monthly. She is already five years in cattle breeding and she plans to continue. So now she is applying for a loan in order to buy three livestock for fattening. Gulmira believes that cattle breeding is a very profitable niche and thus she plans to continue. She plans to build a house, increase livestock numbers and buy a car on the profits.

Umatbek S. is 31 and married. He has two sons of three and two years old. Both of them are at home. He works at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. His wife is a teacher of English language at the local school. Umatbek is applying for a loan in order to buy refrigerator. In the near future, he plans to buy a washing machine for his wife. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale

loans.name: Mrs. Oeurn Khin  Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twenty-two people, who live in Prey Chheu Teal village in TaK. province, make up a village bank loan. Mrs. Oeurn K., who was born in 1971, is a village bank president, selected by the other members. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan for varied ways. Mrs. Oeurn K. is a farmer who owns a four-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell in order to support her family. In addition, she is also a pig breeder. She has some problems because her field has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Oeurn K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will buy pig food. Her husband, Mr. Ran Proum, is a village chief. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the other two are enrolled in local school. The youngest one is three years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kuljamila

texts.en: Kuljamila B. is 53 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. She and her family have been living at the same location for 30 years. Her husband currently is employed as a construction worker, and all three of her children currently attend universities. Kuljamila operates a dairy product business at the local market in her town. In the summertime, she purchases a variety of dairy products from wholesalers and resells them. Kuljamila started her dairy business in 2000 and has built a stable business over the years. She is a very hardworking businesswoman and uses her earnings to provide for her children's educations. In the future, she hopes to continue to make her business better and plans to one day open her own dairy shop.  Kuljamila is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a surplus of dairy products to sell during the upcoming winter months when prices for such products traditionally rise.

loans.use: To purchase a surplus of dairy products

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette G., 46, wants to achieve more in life not just for herself but for her family as well. Jeanette lives in GMA, Cavite, north of Manila with her husband, Antonio, who is a carpenter. They have seven children, one of which is in high school, three in elementary and the other three are working.

Jeanette has managed fruit vending business for 15 years now, which caters mainly to people near their residence in GMA. Jeanette buys variety of tropical fruits from local farmers in wholesale basis and sells the same with a minimum markup. Jeanette and Antonio gather a net income of Php3,050 monthly, which they use to meet the needs of the entire family.

She would like to apply for a Php9, 000 loan to purchase additional variety of fruits for selling. Jeanette has been a member of Center for Community Transformation since March 2005 and is faithfully attending their weekly fellowship meeting*. She hopes that this loan will increase volume of her fruit items to boost sales and eventually expand her business.

Jeanette is determined not to be swayed by problems and struggles in life and aims to make her business grow. She prays to find a commercial area where her business could thrive and flourish. More importantly, she dreams of seeing her children finish their studies and be used as one family for the glory of the Lord whom they serve.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buy more varieties of fresh tropical fruits for selling

loans.name: Azenith

texts.en:
Azeneth R. joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc., Rizal Central Branch, a partner Microfinance Institution of KIVA in the Philippines in the year 2008. Because of her good performanc,e she enjoys the benefit given only to those outstanding members of ASHI. She is 32 years old, married to Horacio, and is blessed with three children. Their eldest, Prince Harish, is 10, Heart Steven is 8, and Rain Sea is 2 years old. 

Their means of livelihood is fishing. Ms. R. is applying for a loan to buy fish nets, bamboo poles and Tilapia and Milkfish fingerlings to expand their fish cage. They’ve been doing this business for almost 4 years now, that is why the couple is confident that they can earn additional profit of Php8,000.00 in three months alone. In this case, it would be a big help for the family, for they can save for their daily expenses and support the schooling of their children. Their utmost dream is to build their own beautiful house and provide their children better way of living.

Both husband and wife are industrious and motivated to improve their situation and enjoy a much better life. With sincerity they want to express their gratitude to ASHI and KIVA lenders and hope they will be granted again help from both institutions to meet their goals in life.

loans.use: Buy tilapia and milkfish fingerlings, fish nets and bamboo poles to expand fish cages

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munhtsetseg M. is a 37-year-old widow who lives with her two teenage daughters in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. Both of her daughters currently attend the local high school. Munhtsetseg operates a small food-selling business at the local market in her town. She sells a variety of grocery items at a rented stand with the help of her husband. Munhtsetseg started her business in 2000, at first selling only eggs, onions and other small grocery items. After growing her business, she saved enough money to expand her operation to include a fruit stand. 

Muuhtsetseg is an honest and focused businesswoman. She works hard to improve her business so that she can provide her daughters with a quality education. Munhtsetseg is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to replenish her fresh fruits supplies.

loans.use: To replenish her fresh fruits supplies

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly G. is from the town of Banga. She is 54 years old. Nelly is married. To make a living, Nelly owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also runs a sari-sari store where she sells a variety of different products. Nelly wishes to have a happy and healthy family.

Nelly joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelly has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nelly is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and additional store inventory. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nelly from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and additional store inventory

loans.name: Mr. Moeun Kruoch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Moeun K., 53, is married with four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory while the others are laborers. His wife, Mrs. Saroum Hun, is employed by a private company. Moeun is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land upon which he cultivates rice to sell. He also raises pigs. The family lives in Prey Chheu Teal village in Takeo province.

Moeun was selected as the village’s bank president by its other twenty-four members who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. Moeun’s problem is that his field is not fertile. To improve his production, he is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and to hire both a plowing machine and farm laborers. With the rest of the loan he will buy more piglets.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire a plowing machine and laborers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start a computer selling and maintenance shop

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza G. is from the town of Banga. She is 42 years old. Flordeliza is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Flordeliza owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Flordeliza wants to have a good business. That's why she is working hard to achieve it.

Flordeliza joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Flordeliza is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inplements. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Flordeliza from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inplements

loans.name: Rosamar

texts.en:
Rosamar G. is from the town of Banga. She is 26 years old. Rosamar is married and has 2 young children. She is a farmer and has been planting and harvesting rice for more than a few years now. She and her husband work hard to keep their farm productive. When not busy at the farm, her husband drives a tricycle (three-whelled mototaxi) to earn extra money while she takes care of their little kids. Rosamar wants to have a happy and healthy family.

Rosamar joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosamar has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rosamar is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Aizat's Group

texts.en:
Aizat E., leader of the group, is 35 and married. She has four children: three sons of fourteen, five, and four years old, and daughter of fifteen years old. Her elder son and daughter go to school, and her two younger sons are at home. Her husband combines his job as mechanic at the company “Shumkar” and cattle breeding. Aizat is a worker at the company “Shumkar” and gets 6500 monthly. After their marriage, ten years ago, they started cattle breeding together from purchase of a cow. Together, they increased livestock numbers to thirteen and the cattle number to two. Monthly, cattle breeding brings 9000 soms. 

Now, Aizat and her husband are preparing their house for the winter period. In order to provide living conditions for their children, they need to make repairs at their house. Unfortunately, they don’t have a sufficient amount of money. They are applying for loan in order to buy building materials and make all the necessary repairs at home in time.

Group members:

Nurgul S., treasurer of the group, is 39 and married. She has two children. Her daughter is fifteen and goes to school. Her son is three years old and is at home. Her husband is in construction, and Nurgul is a poultry woman at the company “Shumkar.” Like Aizat and her husband, Nurgul with her husband decided to make home repairs for the winter period.

Bolotbek B. is 44 and married. He has three daughters of two, five and nine years. The elder daughter goes to school, the second daughter goes to kindergarten, and the youngest is at home. His wife works at the company “Shumkar.”  Five years ago, Bolotbek’s relatives offered him the oppotunity to buy coal at low price in Karakeche and resell it at higher price in the Issykkul region. He started it with 20,000 soms, and it now brings 10,000 soms each month. He is planning to build a big house for his family. Unfortunately, he cannot yet afford it. Therefore, he decided to make just repairs at his house. However, he doesn’t have enough funds. Thus, Bolotbek is applying for a loan in order to buy building materials and make necessary repairs himself.

Zharkyn Z. is 22 and single. She is a student but is expected to graduate this year from International Academy. At present, she is waitress at cafe “Zhibek Zholu”. She lives with her parents. Her father makes profits on buying and selling coal. This autumn her last academic year will start. She wants to prepare herself and buy all necessary things for the studying process including clothing. She cannot buy it herself right, now but in the future she will have enough funds to repay all this money. Therefore she is applying for a loan. In the future, she is planning to graduate and work according to her specialization.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase building materials

loans.name: Mrs. Vasna Maen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eighteen people make up this village bank loA. and they live in Kampong village in the Takeo province. Mrs. Vasna M., born in 1970, is the village bank president who was selected by the other members. They will use their portions of the loA. in various ways to support their families. 

Mrs. Vasna M. and her husband, Mr. Sokoeun Kong, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support their family; moreover, she is a Khmer cake seller in the local village while her husband is a barber. Through those activities, they are trying to work a lot but they cA. earn very little money to support their family. 

So to improve this condition, Mrs. Vasna M. is seeking a loA. to buy two piglets for breeding to start a new business. With the rest of the loA., she will purchase fertilizer. She is a mother of five children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while two others are studying in school and the youngest one is 6 years old.

loans.use: To buy two piglets for breeding

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and peppers to resell

loans.name: Jeksanbai

texts.en:
Jeksanbai T. is 42 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family have been living together at their current address since 2006. Jeksanbai's wife is currently unemployed, and three of his children are students. Jeksanbai operates a transport business in his local area using his own large Russian transport truck. He transports various heavy loads for people and local businesses between Hovd and the neighboring Bayan-ulgiy province. When business is slow, Jeksanbai sometimes purchases flour from wholesalers to transport and sell for himself, and during the cold winter months transports and sells coal. 

Jeksanbai works hard to save his earnings. His main goal is to provide all of his children a quality education. He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase fuel and make repairs to his transport truck.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and make repairs to his transport truck.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma G. is from the town of Banga. She is 38 years old and married. Vilma is involved in farming. She says she first learned planting and harvesting rice crops from her parents, who were farmers also. Now, she and her husband maintain their own farm. She also plants fruit trees like pomelo trees. She sells her harvest to the market.

Vilma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm needs. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Vilma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and other farm needs

loans.name: Seiil's Group

texts.en:
Seiil I. is leader of the group. She is 37 and divorced. Her son is 3 years old and he lives with her relatives. She cannot give her son as much attention as he deserves because she needs to work. Seiil lives with her father, who does cattle breeding. With the help of her father, Seiil increased number of livestock to 150. Seiil, in turn, is a pear sorter. She is planning to move to Karakol and start collecting potatoes. In order to perform field work collecting potatoes, she needs help. Still, she doesn’t have an opportunity to obtain technical provision due to absence of finance. Therefore, she applied for a loan that would assist her performing field work and get higher profits. Higher profits will provide for her son and herself.  

Group members:

Sharymkul Z. is treasurer of the group. She is 61 and married. She has a son. Her son is 17 and he goes to school. Her husband is a pensioner (retiree). Together with her husband, Sharymkul breeds cattle. Sharymkul and her husband started breeding cattle when they were children because their parents also bred cattle. After their marriage, she continued breeding cattle together with her husband. For now, they could increase the livestock number to five, the cattle number to two, and one horse. In line with cattle breeding, they decided to start agriculture. Still, for field work they need help. They are applying for a loan to buy necessary provisions. During autumn, Sharymkul with her husband are planning on doing crop gathering. With the profits, they are planning to give their son a higher education.

Gulkaiyr Z. is 30 and married. She has six children: her daughters are 13, 12, 11 9 and 7 years old, andher son is 5 years old. Her husband earns money fishing. He also breeds cattle. Gulkair, in turn, assists her husband in cattle breeding and in taking care of their house. Her husband started cattle breeding when he was a child. After his marriage, his parents gave him a significant number of livestock. Thus, he decided to continue. For now, they have 5 cattle and 2 horses. The academic year is starting soon, therefore she needs to buy her children school supplies and clothes.

Zharkynai K. is 33 and married. She has four children: her daughters are 13, 11, and 3 years old, and her son is 5 years old. Two elder daughters go to school and the younger daughter and son are at home. Her husband is a worker in the village. Zharkynai is pear sorter, and she is planning to start farming. They started cattle breeding together after their marriage with the cattle that her husband had before their marriage. Now, they have two cows. She needs to prepare her two elder children for the academic year. Therefore, she is applying for a loan in order to buy school supplies. They wish to give the best education to their children so that they could become specialists in their chosen fields and get out of poverty.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=13.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To hire help for collecting potatoes

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie E. is from the town of Banga. He is 29 years old. Jessie is single. To make a living, Jessie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jessie wants to live simply and be happy. He also dreams to have his own family someday. That's why he works hard now to save for it.

Jessie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jessie is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm items. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jessie from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm items

loans.name: Able God Group

texts.en:
Alfred K., who is holding the sign in the photo, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Able God. Alfred is 30 years old, married, and has two children who range from 1 to 5 years old. He was only able to attend school through the 7th grade due to poverty. 

For 3 years, he has been selling slippers in Redlight Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. 

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more slippers. He describes himself as a hard-working man.

His dream is to improve his business and continue to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more slippers for resale

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en:
Ganhuyag B. is 36 years old and lives with his mother in Hovd province in western Mongolia. They live together in a traditional Mongolian house-tent called a ger. Ganhuyag operates a metal home goods trading business at the local market in his town. He takes sheet metal and forms many small products such as buckets, washtubs, dustpans, etc., from them. His mother helps to sell the products at their stall in the market. 

Ganhuyag started his business in 2000 and has built a stable operation over the years. His earnings have enabled him to pay half of the money owed on a car he purchased in 2002. Ganhuyag has a very strong work ethic and is a very open-minded person. He says, "I hope to save enough money to build my own house next to my mother's as well as pay the other half owed on my car." Ganhuyag is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of raw materials for his metal products business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of raw materials

loans.name: Shiela

texts.en:
Shiela N. is from the town of Banga. She is 23 years old. Shiela is married and has a 2-year-old child. To make a living, Shiela owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Shiela wishes for her child to have a bright future.

Shiela joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shiela has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Shiela is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Shiela from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Anera

texts.en:
Aneta V. is from the green farm place of San Jose, Antique. She is 30 years old. She is married and has 3 young children. To make a living, Aneta owns & operates buying and selling dry goods in their village and nearby town. 

Aneta has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a week for these activities. In 2005, Aneta joined ASHI to secure access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.

Aneta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASHI. This previous loan was used in her business. Aneta is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stocks and inventory for her business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Aneta from ASHI. She plans to use the additional proceeds generated from the business to develop the business.

She hopes that, with the help of ASHI and KIVA field partner, she can reach her ambition of moving away under the umbrella of poverty, expand her business, and pay for the needs of her children in school.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock and inventory for her business.

loans.name: Dinara's Group

texts.en:
Dinara K., 31, is the leader of this group. She is a widow with three children: her two sons are 12 and 14 and her daughter is 4 years old. Her two sons go to school and her daughter goes to kindergarten. Dinara is a junior nurse at a center of family medicine. She also breeds cattle. At one time, her husband received twelve sheep as dividends so they decided to start cattle breeding. Dinara already has four years of experience in cattle breeding and earns 3,000 KGS monthly. With the profits from cattle breeding, she has bought household appliances. She is applying for a loan in order to buy hay for the cattle so that she may continue breeding them. In the future, she is planning to raise her children and give them high-quality education.

Group members:
Gulmira B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 50 and married, with three children. Her elder daughter is married and lives independently, her second daughter is 17 and her son is 12. Her daughter entered Kyrgyz National University and her son goes to school. Her husband is a pensioner and his retirement allowance is 1,600 KGS per month. Gulmira is an accountant. Together with her husband, Gulmira breeds cattle; however, since her husband is already a pensioner, he does most of the work. They started cattle breeding with a purchase of two bulls for 30,000 KGS. They already have ten years of experience in this business and make 6,000 KGS monthly. With the help of the profits, they raised their elder daughter, gave her higher education and bought dowry when she got married. They also were able to use the profits to give their second daughter the opportunity to study at an institution of higher education and have bought a car for the family. They are applying for a loan in order to buy one more bull, fatten and resell it. With these profits, they are planning to buy a dowry for their second daughter.

Nurlan K. is 37 and married. He has three children: his daughter is 5 and his sons are 1 and 3 years old. His wife is a housewife. Nurlan is an expert for the company “ARIS”. He also breeds cattle. He decided to start cattle breeding 17 years ago by using his first salary to purchase cattle. He started cattle breeding with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS and he now makes 7,000 KGS monthly. He is applying for loan in order to buy hay for the cattle. 

Nazira M. is 37 and married. She has two children: her daughter is 8 and her son is 5 years old. Both of them go to school. Her husband is a taxi driver and he receives 8,000 KGS monthly. Two months ago, upon their neighbors' suggestion, they decided to sell vegetables. Since Nazira’s husband is a taxi driver, he drives daily to the capital where he can buy vegetables and other convenience goods at wholesale prices. He then brings them to their town and Nazira sells them at a higher price to the local population. Nazira can make 3,000 KGS per month because she has no transportation costs. Nazira is applying for a loan in order to increase their turnover in purchasing vegetables this autumn. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase hay for her cattle

loans.name: Chanda

texts.en:
Chanda E. is from the town of Banga. She is 28 years old. Chanda is married and has a 5-year-old child. To make a living, Chanda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Chanda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years. Like most farmers in her town, she wants her farm to be productive.

Chanda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Chanda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Chanda is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm inputs, such as seeds and fertilizers. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Chanda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more hair dryers, oil sheen, shampoo, hair grease etc.

loans.name: Festus

texts.en: This is 42 year-old Festus. He is married, and has 2 children aged 4 and 14 years. He has 2 additional dependents who live with him, his elderly mother and an orphan. In 1998, Festus established his Africana slippers, sandals, shoes and VCDs business. He began his business as a travelling salesman but with his additional income he rented a shop and started selling sandals, shoes and VCDs. Working 6 days a week and 9 hours a day, he earns about 954,000 SLL every month from his business. Festus would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL in order to buy slippers, shoes and sandals. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 114,480 SLL. In the future, Festus plans to open another shop for his wife. Festus hopes to put his children through university. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more sandals, slippers and shoes.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 43 years old. Allan is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Allan owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Allan has been engaged in his business for over 6 years.

Allan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Allan has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Allan is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support his family and save as a reserve for emergencies. He wishes CEVI will be able to expand and help more farmers like him.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia F., 53, wants to achieve more in life not just for herself but for her family. Rosalia lives in GMA, Cavite with her four children, one of whom is in high school, and the other three in elementary.

Rosalia has managed her own fruit and vending business for 15 years. She grows some of the vegetables in her garden in her backyard. Everyday she manages to sell vegetables and tropical fruits at her stall. Her main customers are people near their residence in GMA, Cavite. Rosalia gathers a net income of 2000 PHP monthly, which she uses to meet the needs of her entire family.

Rosalia is applying to CCT* for a 8000 PHP loan to enhance her business and increase her profits. She plans to purchase a variety of tropical fruits to add to her current inventory. The loan will serve as an additional capital that will enable Rosalia to make her business more profitable and lead to more savings.

She hopes to expand her business and also to start up a junk shop as another business. More importantly, she dreams of seeing her children finish their studies and her family used for the glory of the Lord whom they serve.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional tropical fruits and vegetables for vending.

loans.name: Dorita

texts.en:
Dorita L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 54 years old. Dorita is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Dorita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Dorita also manages a sari-sari store, where a variety of different products is sold. She says the store also helps in their daily needs. She hopes to be able to sustain the store.

Dorita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dorita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Dorita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and additional store inventory. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Dorita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income and save for emergencies. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure and additional store inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more new movies and DVD discs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: increase the area of cultivated land and buy fertilizer

loans.name: Isezerano Choir Group

texts.fr:
S. Jean Paul  est un homme  de 40 ans, marié, née à Rubavu  un des districts de la province de l’Ouest du Rwanda, son niveau d’étude est primaire. Il a cinq enfants, le plus âgée a 16 ans et son cadet a 5 ans. Un de ses enfants est en deuxième année secondaire d’autres a l’école primaire.
Il appartient dans une chorale chrétienne a l’association des églises de pentecôte du Rwanda œuvra à Rubavu appelé ISEZERANO. Client d’ACB depuis décembre 2008, il  a sollicité un prêt qu’il veut très bien remboursé. C’était pour acheter un champ pour y cultiver les pommes de terre. Son ambition et son souhait et que dans l’avenir et d’avoir un grand étendu de culture des pommes de terre afin de commercialiser la récolte et en tirer du profit , une partie pour épargner et l’autre parti améliorera les conditions de vie de la famille en payant les frais de scolarités pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
Jean Paul S. is a 40-year old married man, born in Rubavu, a district in the West Province of Rwanda. He has finished primary level of studies. He has five children, with the oldest being 16 years of age, and the youngest 5. One of his children is in high school while the others are still in primary school. He is a member of the “Isezerano” Christian choir under the auspices of the association of Pentecostal churches of Rwanda active in Rubavu. He has been a client of ACB since December 2008. He is seeking a loan which he plans to repay properly. The loan is for purchasing a land plot in order to cultivate potatoes. His vision and his dream is to have a sizeable potato-growing business in the future, selling his harvest and using the derived profit for savings as well as for improving the life conditions of his family, such as paying the school fees for his children.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a land plot for cultivating potatoes

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie D., age 31, is married and has three children currently attending high school. She and her husband work hard each day to cover daily expenses and the cost of their children's education. Virgie runs her own store selling fishballs, squidballs, and ice cream, among other goods, and generates PHP5,000 a month in earnings.

Virgie has requested a loan of Php28,000 to help her expand her inventory and attract more customers.  The new loan will allow her to buy groceries in bulk, saving money on transportation. She hopes that with more working capital her business will generate more stable revenues for her and her family.

Virgie has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2005 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes to someday further expand her business and fully fund her children's education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: increase her farmland and buy fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia G., age 59, is married and has two children of working age. Amelia and her husband work hard to cover daily expenses and Amelia has been running her own clothing and tailoring store for more than ten years.

Amelia relies on having a constant supply of fabric and other tailoring materials to keep her business running, and has requested a loan of PHP 20,000 to help her purchase additional inventory. Amelia hopes the additional materials will help her cater to customers' demands on various designs and styles of clothing they want. By so doing, it helps her to expand her business.

Amelia has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2006 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes for a happy and stable life for her family, and would like her business to continue to expand.  

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: extend the arable land she farms and buy fertilizer to improve the soil.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Aminata is married and has 4 children. Aminata sells plastic products and cosmetics at the central market in Makeni city. She has 7 years experience in this type of business. Aminata is dedicated and determined to succeed in business. She opens her business at 7 am and closes it by 7 pm.

Aminata was initially financed by her husband. She has a good loan repayment history. Aminata needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to buy additional plastic footwear. She hopes to help her husband finish their house that is presently under construction and educate her kids. She thanks you for supporting her.

loans.use: To buy plastic footwear for her stall.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more gallons of red oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her arable land and buy fertilizers for her soil

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou G., age 48, is married with three children, one in school, one working, and one currently at home. Marilou and her husband work hard to pay daily expenses, and to cover the cost of their children's education. For the past sixteen years, Marilou has owned and run her own sari-sari store (general store) selling snacks, soft drinks, and other goods. 

Marilou has requested a loan of PHP 31,000 to help her expand her inventory, and hopefully attract new customers. Marilou is looking to expand her business and finds that the loans allow her to buy inventory in bulk, saving on transportation costs and allowing her to spend more time running the store.  

Marilou has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2008 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that her business will continue to generate income and that her family will live a happy and stable life.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cotton material and ink at wholesale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorcycle taxi

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Winner B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called In God we Trust. Winner is 38 years old, single, and has two children who range from 9 to 16 years old. She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to poverty. 

For more than 2 years, she has been selling red oil in Redlight Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 7,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 35,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more gallons of red oil. She describes herself as a kind woman.

Her goal is to grow her business, and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of red oil.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
This is Arlene R., 48, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Nelson R., a housepainter, and mother of a young adult who is currently enrolled in college. By the grace of God, Arlene has managed to support her child's schooling up to college level. A dream for most Filipino parents like Arlene, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Arlene operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene gets supplies at wholesale prices and sells them at a per piece rate. Arlene’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Arlene dreams of being able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing her arable land and buying fertilizers

loans.name: Habibahon's Group

texts.en:
Habibahon A. is the leader of the group. She is 44 and divorced. She has raised two sons and three daughters. The sons work in construction, two older daughters are married and live separately with their families, and the youngest daughter works in Russia. Habibahon is engaged in livestock breeding, and she started this activity in 1995. When the collective farms broke up, she got a half hectare of land and began to cultivate cotton.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase sheep in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future, she plans to purchase a piece of land and start building a house for her son.

Abdimumin T., 59, is a widow.  He has raised three sons, and all of them work in construction in Russia. He uses the money which his sons send to him for building a house. Abdimumin himself works as a taxi driver and earns 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan he plans to finish building the house. In the future he wants to see his sons get married, purchase a piece of land, and breed cattle.

Feruza S., 28, is married. She has a son and two daughters. The first daughter and the son are at school and the second daughter is not yet, as she is preschool age (under 7). Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 8000 soms, Feruza started to breed livestock. Reselling cattle after fattening, she makes 4000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase sheep in order to resell them after fattening at the higher price.

Kamolathon A. is 21, and she lives with her parents. Her father is an engineer and her mom is engaged in farming. Kamolathon is engaged in cattle breeding, and she sells milk to make money. In this way, she makes 1250 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase hay for cattle to feed them during the winter season.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 26 years old and is married with one child.

In 2003 he opened a food market in a residential area where demand is high. His reputation in his local community is good.

He is requesting a loan of $3,000 from Kiva partner, CHF-ACSI which he wants to invest in increasing his stock and installing roll shutters for his shop entrance. He is planning to add new and different products in the future.

loans.use: To increase his stock and to install roll shutters for his shop entrance

loans.name: Redempta

texts.en:
This is Redempta L., 42, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Jose L. and mother to three children, one of whom is in college, one in high school, while the youngest is in elementary school. They are blessed in their marriage with good health and strong physiques, which enable them to work hard for their future together.

Redempta operates a ready-to-wear clothing store. She mainly offers children’s clothing, summer shorts (which are very popular in tropical Philippines), statement shirts, and other basic everyday wear. These clothing items are made from sheer cotton fabrics, which are all suited to the hot and humid climate. Most customers only buy made to order clothes when it is really necessary, as it is more expensive. Elena’s customers are her immediate community and neighbors.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and designs of clothing to replenish and increase her current business inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  
Redempta dreams of being able to have her own house and lot some day through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes that her children will finish their education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and designs of clothing to replenish and increase her current business inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his field

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Mariatu is married to a trader and they have two children who are attending school. She has traded for seven years in palm oil, rice, and vegetables in Makeni city. Mariatu is very determined to see that her business continues to grow. She opens her business at 7 am and closes by 7:30 pm.She has basic business skills.

Mariatu has a good credit history. She needs a loan of 4,000,000SLL, to buy additional palm oil and rice for resale. She intends to use the proceeds from this loan to educate her kids and buy a piece of land. She thanks you for supporting her.

loans.use: To buy palm oil and vegetables.

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.en:
Eugenie was born in 1979 and is married with three children aged between 5 and 9. She has owned a small business since 2006 selling shoes. Her husband is a businessman and they both work hard so that they provide all the basic needs of their children. Eugenie’s business is well organized and her daily activities start at 6 in the morning until 6 in the evening, every day except Sunday.

Eugenie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business. This will allow her to satisfy her customers, which is the best way of earning enough profits to use for her business and for her particular problems as well.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: expand her acreage and buy fertilizer

loans.name: Good People Group

texts.en:
Mai F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Good People. Mai is 49 years old, married, and has five children who range from 15 to 31 years old. She was only able to attend school through 4th grade due to poverty. 

For 13 years, she has been operating a mini restaurant in 72nd, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 41,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more gallons of cooking oil, bags of rice, meat, fish, beans, etc. She describes herself as a quiet woman.

Her dream is to grow her business, and continue to educate her children.

In the photo that accompanies this, Massa is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of cooking oil, bags of rice, meat, fish, beans, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of sheet metal, stones, sand, ciment and manual labor

loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en:
Mabinty is married to a trader who is an active partner in the business. She has 5 dependants.

Mabinty sells different types of cloth such as cotton and lace in Makeni city. She started trading fifteen years ago, when her husband provided the first business capital for her. Mabinty is very hard working and determined to keep her business going. She opens her business at 7 am and closes at 7 pm daily.

Mabinty has a very good loan repayment history. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to buy additional cotton and lace materials in order to meet the tastes of her customers for the coming Ramadan.

She hopes to use the proceeds of the loan to educate her children and to support her husband in building a house. She thanks you for supporting her.

loans.use: To purchase cloth materials like lace and cotton.

loans.name: Hashem

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 26 years old and is a married man with two children.

Since 2003 he has owned a garage where he fixes cars although the place is rented. He is well known in his local community and has good manners.

He is requesting a loan of $2,100 from Kiva partner, CHF-ACSI, which he wants to invest in renovating his garage and buying a scanner machine for cars.

He is working on developing his business and increasing his revenues.

loans.use: To renovate his garage and buy a scanner machine

loans.name: Yudaya

texts.en:
Yudaya N. lives in Namungoona, a neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has 2 children, one of whom is in school.

Yudaya has a business of selling samosas and chapatti. She has been in this business for 9 years, and she works 5 days out of every week. Yudaya sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. Yudaya has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerrycans of cooking oil, wheat flour, and charcoal.

The main business challenge(s) for Yudaya include seasonality and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy land and start farming. She decided to work with MCDT because it reaches out to clients at a grassroots level. Yudaya lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include medication, food, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of cooking oil, wheat flour, and charcoal.

loans.name: Blessing Group

texts.en:
Bendu K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Blessing. Bendu is 32 years old, married, and has two children who range from 1 to 8 years old.

She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to poverty. 

For 3 years, she has been selling onions, peppers, tomatoes, and salt in Redlight Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 26,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more onions, peppers, tomatoes, and salt. She describes herself as a caring mother.

Her goal is to improve her business, educate her children, and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more onions, peppers, tomatoes, and salt.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: expand her acreage and buy fertilizer

loans.name: Mediatrice

texts.en:
Mediatrice is 38 years old and is married with three children: the first one is 17, the next is 15 and the last is 13 years old.

Mediatrice owns a business selling maize flour. She has been a businesswoman for a long time, obviously, because she has an experience of ten years in her business. However, even though she is seasoned in her business, she is not able to satisfy her customers. 

Mediatrice is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to be used in her business. With this loan, she will be able to attract more customers which will help her to earn more profits through selling larger quantities.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: stocking and sale of kerosene and motor oil

loans.name: Khaldoun

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old, is married, and is responsible for his family.

He rented a place to open his own business as a salesperson, selling women's clothes and accessories, plus home supplies. He has run his shop for more than three years and he likes his job because, in his opinion, it's a profitable and continuous business since his products are necessities. He is well-known and respectable in his local community.

He is requesting a loan of $2,400 from Kiva partner, CHF-ACSI. He wants to invest it in buying new products and renovating his shop.

loans.use: To buy new products and to renovate his shop

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is married to a carpenter with whom they have six children; four of her children go school. She gave birth to twins who are three months old.  She doesn’t take care of additional family members.

Previously, she owned a ladies' salon. She now owns a stall selling bananas in Kalerwe market. She buys bananas from the villages of Masaka District and uses public transport to buy bananas once a week. She doesn’t have any other side job. She sells to all kinds of people, both retail and wholesale. Justine works six days a week.

Her business challenges are transportation and seasonality. She aspires to being able to buy a plot of land. Justine decided to join MCDT, because of their timely loans and also services that are nearby. She resides in and rents a two-room house and the family has access to electricity, but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses are rent, medication, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Weedor S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Is Able. Weedor is 38 years old, married and has two children who are 15 and 18 years old. She was only able to attend school through 4th grade due to poverty.

For 7 years Weedor has been selling onions, peppers, tomatoes and salt in Redlight Market, Paynesville outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 14,000 LRD portion of this 56,000 LRD group loan to buy more onions, peppers, tomatoes and salt.

Her dream is to improve her business, educate her children, and build a house. She describes herself as a jovial woman.

In the photo, Elizabeth is inset at the lower right, because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more onions, peppers, tomatoes and salt.

loans.name: Berna

texts.en:
Berna N. lives in the Kawempe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is in school. She also takes care of additional family members.

Berna has a business of selling beer and local gin. She has been in business for 9 years and she works 7 days out of every week. Berna sells her products from home, by means of retail.

Berna has requested a loan of 800000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer. The main business challenges for Berna include seasonality and defaulters.

Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot of land and to start selling on wholesale only. Berna lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees.
