loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

location.town: San Pablo Proper, Cauayan City, Isabela

loans.name: Floreliza

texts.en:
Floreliza C. is a single woman who lives in Sitio Saksak, Barangay Buanoy, Balamban, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures, a sari-sari (variety) store and a food vending business. 

Floreliza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Floreliza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 20,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of $135, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing 20,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase additional products for her sari-sari store business so that she can continue to save up for the future and for a down payment on a 50 square meter lot and for house repair. Floreliza C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of stock to sell

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios S. is from the village of Santo Domingo, Alicia, Isabela. She is 46 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She is just starting this business.

In 2010, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody F. is a 34-year old married who supports her family by operating two business ventures, a general store and a buy and sell business. She lives in Guimbal, Barangay Canamucan, Compostela, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her general store and her buy and sell businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of about $188. Melody is now borrowing 17,000 PHP which she will use as additional working capital for her general store.  This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Melody aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
La Señora María Elena vive en las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad se levanta sobre la antigua ciudad inca de Tomebamba,  tiene un clima frió, amenos paisajes del entorno, la abundancia de agua y la fama de sus habitantes por su habilidad de orfebres y ceramistas hacen de esta ciudad una de las más bellas del Ecuador.

Doña María se encuentra en su segundo crédito que realiza en la banca comunal y fue una compañera la que la incentivo a formar parte de este grupo de mujeres que buscan un mejor porvenir, trabaja como secretaria de un radio taxi en el cual lleva 8 años, su horario de trabajo es de domingo a domingo en horarios rotativos, también vende productos YANBAL, en este negocio lleva 3 años, los vende en su tiempo libre y nos comenta que los créditos le han beneficiado mucho en su negocio.

La Señora. María tiene 29 año, es casada y tiene un hijo  de 8 años de edad, su esposo es empleado privado, no poseen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando. El nuevo crédito que la FUNDACION ESPOIR le hace entrega lo va a invertir en la compra de productos YANBAL. Su sueño  es  estudiar medicina.
texts.en:
María Elena lives in the outskirts of the city of Cuenca which is built above the ancient Inca city of Tomebamba. Its climate is cold, it has pleasant surroundings, an abundance of water and its residents are famous for their silver and ceramic crafts thus making this city one of Ecuador’s most beautiful. María is in her 2nd loan with the communal bank. She was encouraged by a coworker to become part of this group of women who seek a better future. She’s been employed as a secretary at a radio-dispatch taxi firm for 8 years. She works rotating shifts from Sunday to Sunday. She has also sold YANBAL products for 3 years in her free time and she mentioned to us that the loans have been very beneficial to her business. María is 29 years old, married and has an 8-year-old son. Her husband is a private employee. They do not own their home, they are renters. The new loan that FUNDACION ESPOIR will grant will be used to buy YANBAL products. Her dream is to study medicine.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Yanbal brand cosmetics and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet G. is from the village of Santo Domingo, Alicia, Isabela. She is 39 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes C. is a married woman who lives in Park Punta, Barangay Hilutungan, Bantayan, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating a fishing business.  Her husband, Santos C., who is 39 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 12 and 13 years old. 

Mercedes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mercedes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 11,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of approximately $170, raising the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more fishing gear and equipment so that she can continue to save up for future tuition fees and for daily expenses. Mercedes C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann D. is from the village of San Juan, Alicia, Isabela. She is 28 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling home products in the local community. Mary Ann is just starting this business.

In 2010, Mary Ann joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

loans.name: Derlina

texts.en:
Derlina D. C. is a married woman who lives in Purok Toril, Barangay Paraiso, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business.  Her husband, Welbin D. C., who is 48 years old, works as a driver to earn his living. They have four children who are between 15 years old to less than a year. 

Derlina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Derlina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 13,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of approximately $465, raising the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 7th loan, she is borrowing 14,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more fish for her business so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Derlina D. C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Thach's Group

texts.en:
Four people are members of this group loan.  Mrs. K. Thach, 45 years old, is the group leader of the loan, having been selected by all the members who live in Preak Reang village, Kandal province. All members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. K. Thach and her husband are grocery sellers in the local market. With this business, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Since their business is going well, K. Thach will use the loan from AMK to buy more groceries to resell. This couple has two children: One is a seamstress in a garment factory and one is employed by an organization.

texts.en:
Dino B. is from the village of Santo Domingo, Alicia, Isabela. He is 26 years old, married, and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, he raises pigs for fattening and sale. He has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately $100 when he sells his raised animals.

In 2010, Dino joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family.

loans.name: Mrs. Chanda Soung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people make up this village bank loan based in Tang Ruessei village in Takeo province. They have selected Mrs. Chanda S., who was born in 1968, as their village bank president. They will each use their portion of the loan in different ways to support their businesses. 

Mrs. Chanda S. is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Now she has a problem because her field is infertile. So, to improve production, Mrs. Chanda S. is applying fO. a loan to buy fertilizer. She will use the rest of the loan to hire a plow to plow her field. Her husband, Mr. Reth Nget, is a motorcycle taxi driver. She is the mother of three children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina M. is a 52-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a fruit-selling and general store, a pig fattening business and a farming business. She lives in Purok Mabinoligon, Barangay Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fruits/general store, and in her pig fattening and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of about $210 a month. 

Medina is now borrowing 16,000 PHP so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Medina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.name: Mrs. Phally Ouch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank consists of fifteen people who live in Tang Ruessei village in Takeo province. Mrs. Phally O. is a village bank president who was born in 1973, selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan in various ways.

She is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family, while her husband, Mr. Ren Son, is a soya-bean seller door-to-door. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production Mrs. Phally O. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of six children, two of whO. are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other three are enrolled in local school, and the youngest one is five years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
The middle aged woman in the photograph is Man R., age 35. She lives in a rural area of province of Phnom Penh, which is the best territory for farming. Man R. is a married mother who is devoted to her three teenage children. One of her sons is no longer in school and currently works in the construction field.

Man R. owns a big farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows various crops on it. She also relies on the income from her husband, who owns a motorcycle to provide a taxi service. Man R. can’t earn as much income as before because his motor-taxi is getting too old and often breaks down. To help solve the problem, Man R. needs a loan for her husband to use to replace his old motor-taxi.

loans.use: To replace an old motor-taxi.

loans.name: Babylyn

texts.en:
Babylyn L. is from the village of Santo Domingo, Alicia, Isabela. She is 38 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she  owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $90 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Babylyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Babylyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong P., 47 years old, is a humble villager living in the capital, Phnom Penh, in the middle of Cambodia. She was married but divorced her husband when her four kids (two sons and two daughters) were very young. All of her children are now teenagers who are no longer in school and work at different occupations.

To earn a living, Kong P. sells many kinds of vegetables, which she either buys in bulk from her supplier or grows them. She doesn’t have her own vehicle, so Kong P. always has to hire a taxi to transport vegetables from her farm supplier to the market. Kong P. is taking her first loan to buy a new motorcycle that she can use to pick up vegetables or to travel anywhere else without hiring taxis. Mrs. Kong P. was not available when the photo taken, so her son is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to pick up vegetables or to travel anywhere else.

loans.name: Mrs. Sopheap Sot Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The twelve people who make up this village bank loan are located in Tang Ruessei village in Takeo province. They selected Mrs. Sopheap S., born in 1964, as a village bank president. They will all will use their portion of their loan for different purposes.

She and her husband, Mr. Sok Chea Ket, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to support their family, and he is a recycled materials seller who earns some money to support his family. Since business is doing well, she wants to expand. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Sopheap S. is requesting a loan to buy more recycled materials to resell. She is a mother of five children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, another is a construction worker, the other two are studying in school, and the youngest one is three years old.

loans.use: To buy more recycled materials to resell.

loans.name: Dol

texts.en: Dol S. is a longtime businessman who earns a living fishing as well as by providing a taxi service. Dol S. lives with other family members in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. He is married with nine children: three are married and live independently and the other six are single. Three of his children are employed and provide their little income for the family’s living expenses. His wife (in the photo) sells vegetables that she buys in bulk from a supplier, as well as growing them at home. Dol S. is taking out this loan to purchase a motorcycle to provide transportation for the family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to provide transportation for the family.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica A. is a married woman who lives in Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures, a pig fattening and a motorcycle business. Her husband, Vicente A., is 35 years old and works as a driver. They have four children aged 6 to 14 years. Veronica joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. 

With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Veronica has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP helped her to earn a monthly profit of 8,000 PHP, thus raising her family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, she is borrowing 12,000 PHP to buy more piglets so that she can continue to save for the future and send her children to school. Veronica A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Jorgie

texts.en:
Jorgie D. is one of the best performing members of the Rizal East Branch of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc., a Kiva partner in the Philippines. Jorgie is 38 years old and is married with three children of whom two are studying.

Jorgie joined ASHI in 2005 and, since that time, she has shown consistency in her performance as a member. Because of her very good performance, her family has benefited from the loans she received from ASHI. She was able to support her husband in their financial needs and they were able to start a business: the family was able to put up a store where they sell motorcycle spare parts and accessories and different brands of gear and motor oil.

This time, Jorgie is applying for another loan to fund her business. The demand is high in their location so she decided to apply for additional capital. With the loan, she will buy more oil products and motorcycle parts and will renovate and expand their store space to be more pleasing to their customers. Since they started this business, their profit has increased and, with this new loan, they are pretty sure they will gain more profit.

The couple’s dream is to become entrepreneurs someday and live a better life. They also want their children to finish college and earn a degree. All of their dreams are slowly coming to life and they are very thankful there are institution like ASHI and Kiva helping less fortunate families like them to achieve their dreams.

loans.use: To buy more oil products and motorcycle parts and to renovate and expand their store

loans.name: Mrs. Sarann Yin Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has twenty-three members who live in Tuol Trea village, in TaK. province.  Sarann Y. is the bank's president, selected by the members.  Each member will use their portion of the loan to support their families. 

Sarann is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice that she sells to support her family.  She is also a pig breeder.  Her husband is a village chief and construction worker. 

Since her pig breeding business is going well, she wants to expand.  Sarann is seeking a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, and to hire farm laborers to grow rice. 

Sarann is a mother of four children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the others go to school and help their parents..

loans.use: Buy piglets, pig food and more.

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Sajida lives in a small city called Kot Radha Kishen which is a located in Punjab province of Pakistan. Kot Radha Kishen is famous for its agriculture and dairy industry.  She is 36 years old married to G. and a mother of three children, two sons and a daughter. Sajida is aware of the importance of education and that’s why she is why she is sending them in nearby school. Her daughter is studying in 5th grade and sons are in 9th and 8th grades respectively. Sajida is Christian by religion and lives in a 2 room brick house with her family in the area of Clarkabad.  Her husband operates a grocery shop in his house. He has dedicated a room for this purpose and sells cooking oil, lentils, rice, spices and other household items. He has been doing this business for the last 15 years. Sajida is very supportive in nature. Though she is a house wife, she works at the grocery shop in the absence of her husband.  

Sajida has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to use the loan to buy more grocery items for his shop. By adding more variety of groceries Sajida hopes that her husband will be able to earn extra income and improves his business condition.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 7th loan cycle. In previous loans she has proven to be a good client. She never missed any meeting and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for a grocery shop

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios P. is from the village of Cabisera 8. She is 40 years old. Remedios is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Remedios owns & operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing & selling  charcoal to community members. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture charcoal and additional products. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture charcoal and additional products. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Remedios from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture charcoal and additional products

loans.name: Shi's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Shi K., age 47, was selected as the village bank president by the fifteen members of this village loan. They are located in Tranh village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses.

Mrs. Shi K. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that they use to cultivate rice for a living. She will use the loan that she requested from AMK for this farm, to buy fertilizer, and pesticide to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Yorn Yang, is a laborer, and is able to receive a small salary to add to his wife's savings to support the family. This couple has a child, who is a student in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Mrs. Pov Ek Village Bank Group

texts.en: Seventeen people make up this village bank loan and they live in Tuol Trea village, in TaK. province. Mrs. Pov E., who was born in 1966, is a village bank president, as selected by the other group members. Each group member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Pov E. and her husband, Mr. Mai Dy, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land on which they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Although they try to work a lot, she can earn very a little money to support their family. So to improve her family's condition, Mrs. Pov E. is applyI. for a loan to buy some piglets for breedI. to start a new business. With the rest of the loan she will buy some fish for breedI. as well. She is a mother of two children, all of whom are studyI. in school and they are helpI. in their parents’ businesses.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Shailina

texts.en:
This is Shailina S., 37, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Joel S., a driver, and she is a mother of four children, one of is in high school while the younger children are in elementary. By the grace of God, Shailina has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all her children through college. Shailina was a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children, a dream for most Filipino parents

Shailina operates a food business. She sells frozen cuts of cured, sweetened and spiced meats like pork, sausages, hotdogs and hams. She also manufactures sweet peanut butter and coco jam (sweet jam from coconuts, used for fillings), a popular bread filling which is a hit to adults and youngsters alike. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php150 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a Php13, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of cured meats. She also will invest some of the loan to buy raw ingredients for her coco jam and peanut butter. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Shailina dreams to be able to give her all her children a good quality education through all her hard work with her business. She also plans to buy  another tricycle. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of cured meats and raw ingredients for her coco jam and peanut butter

loans.name: Florinda

texts.en:
Florinda F. is from the village of Cabisera 8. She is 51 years old. Florinda is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Florinda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Florinda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2009, Florinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Florinda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Florinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma T. is from the village of Cabisera 8. She is 39 years old. Norma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Norma owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling meat in the local community. Norma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 27000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Norma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Norma is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Norma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en:
Preciosa M. is from the village of Cabisera 8. She is 55 years old. Preciosa is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Preciosa owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general  alteration & tailoring services to local community members. Preciosa has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Preciosa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Preciosa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Preciosa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie Q., age 48, and her husband have eight children, five of whom are in school. The couple work hard to cover their daily expenses and provide for their children's education.  For the past ten years Melanie has owned and run a sari-sari store (general store) and small salon providing manicures, pedicures, and massages.  

Melanie has requested a PHP 10,000 loan to purchase snacks and other groceries for her sari-sari store in hopes that the additional inventory will help attract more customers and increase her sales.  Loans allow her to buy in bulk, minimizing transportation costs. 

Melanie has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that eventually proceeds from her store will allow her to fully cover her children's educational expenses. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Leang

texts.en: Mr. Leang V. is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He has a few partners to help provide his services. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. He has another financial earner in his wife, who sells meat and groceries to people who are her nearby neighbors. Leang V. has three children, all of whom are enrolled in school and help in their parent’s jobs when they are not studying. The stock of grocery items has been exhausted, so Mr. Leang V. is requesting a loan for his wife use as capital to resupply her grocery inventory. With any remaining cash from the loan, Leang V. will mend his old house that is in need of repair.

loans.use: To resupply the grocery stock.

loans.name: Bayarsaikhan

texts.en:
Mr Bayarsaikhan is 38 years old lives with his wife and three kids in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Two of his children attend a secondary school and one goes to kindergarten. Bayarsaikhan is a chemist-biologist and used to work in a chemical laboratory until 1990 when he was injured and had to leave the job. Since then he is running a transportation business. He owns a minivan and carries people on one of the remote bus lines in Ulaanbaatar City. 

His wife Oyungerel works with him as a cashier. Two years ago they obtained a right to own a piece of land and have done a lot of ground work there because the land was sloping. Their plan in the future is to build a house on it. They are very hardworking and nice people. Every few years they have to renew the van to keep the license for carrying people, because of transportation authorities safety requirements. This summer he has changed his minivan to newer one. He already paid most of the money, but still owes 1,500,000 MNT to the seller. The reason he is asking for this loans is to pay the rest of the money for his minivan. After that he will be able to register the minivan on his name and to continue his business.

loans.use: To improve his minivan and repay the money he owes for the vehicle

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando S. Sr., 46 years old and married, is from the village of Alimannao, Peñablanca, Cagayan where he owns and operates a business venture providing motorcycle transport to local community members. Engaged in his business for over four years, he earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

Fernando joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to repair a motorcycle used in the business, and plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Jeannie

texts.en:
Jeannie O., 36, and her husband Moner, 34, have two children and work hard to cover daily expenses and schooling costs. For the past eight years Jeannie has been operating a fish-selling stand, an arcade with a billiards table, and retailing gasoline for vehicles.

Jeannie is requesting a PHP 9,000 loan to help purchase additional seafood for her store. She is also planning to use part of this loan to purchase a volume of gasoline and diesel for her to retail. She hopes that the additional inventory will attract new customers and help her expand her business.

Jeannie has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.* She hopes that the income from her business will allow her to send her children through school.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Sokea Kham Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Sokea K., who was born in 1989, is a married man and was selected as village bank president by the twenty-one members of the loan which is located in Tranh village, Kandal province. The members of this village loan will use the money to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.

Mr. Sokea K. is a farmer who works very hard to support his family. For this farm, he will use the loan that he has requested from AMK to buy fertilizer to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, he is also a construction worker while his wife, Mrs. Sokrat Duong, is a seamstress in a garment factory. With their occupations they are able to earn a small income to support the family. This couple has a child, age 3, who is not yet in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to cultivate rice.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Turdubiubiu's Group

texts.en:
Turdubiubiu A., 51 and the mother of a 16-year-old daughter who studies in the United States, is the leader of this group. Her husband helps her to keep house and operate her business, a cattle-breeding and milk-selling operation. With an initial investment of 3000 soms, Turdubiubiu started her business four years ago, and she now earns 4600 soms each month. From the profits she has been able to buy home appliances and significantly increase her number of cattle. Turdubiubiu is requesting a loan to purchase hay for the cattle and continue her successful business which provides for the members of her family.

Group members: Buaihan M., 42 and married, is the group's treasurer. She has three children: a daughter, 17, a son, 12, and another daughter, 7. Her husband works in Russia, while her children study in the U.S. For eight years, Buaihan has bred cattle and sold milk, having started the business with the purchase of a cow for 8000 soms. She now earns a monthly income of 3500 soms. Buaihan is requesting a loan to buy more cattle to continue cattle breeding. With the additional profits, she is planning to increase her number of cattle.

Abdyldabek A., 39 and married, has five children: his daughter is 18 and his sons are 16, 14, 9 years old, and 11 months. His daughter works in Russia, while his three elder sons go to school and the youngest son is at home. Abdyldabek breeds cattle and sells milk, assisted by his elder sons. Six years ago, he bought a milk cow for 5000 soms and since then has increased his number of cattle. Abdyldabek now makes 8000 soms each month, and he is applying for loan in order to buy forage for cattle for the winter period.

Asilbek B., 46 and married, has three children: his sons are 14 and 8, and his daughter is 13, and they are all are studying in the U.S. Asilbek started his business three years ago with an initial investment of 500 soms. He makes national items (for example: national souvenirs) and earns 2000 soms monthly. His profits will allow him to start construction of his house. He is now requesting a loan to buy chickens for breeding, the profits from which will allow him to improve the living conditions of his family.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase hay for cattle

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya C., 45 years old, is married and a member of Ahon sa HIrap, Inc.-Rizal East Branch, a  Microfinance Institution partner of KIVA here in the Philippines. Her husband is a tricycle driver. The couple were blessed with one daughter. 

Her performance as member of ASHI is excellent which enabled her to apply for a loan to buy a tricycle. Her husband will drive the tricycle and she manages the daily profit. She is again applying for a loan as down  payment for another motorcycle. Their dream is to increase number of their tricycle units so that they can have more income. Her husband wishes to eventually buy a van for passenger transport in the near future. The additional income will help the couple meet their financial needs and support their daughter. She is thankful to ASHI and KIVA for the continued support they give to her.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Eng K., 40, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. K. and her husband sell groceries for an income of USD 12 per day. K. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. K. appears in the photograph while she is sitting and selling at her shop.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Dionicio

texts.en:
Dionicio B. is from the village of Cabisera 5. He is 45 years old. Dionicio is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Dionicio owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Dionicio has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 20000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Dionicio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dionicio is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Dionicio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. is a housewife while her husband is employed at a local construction company, earning an income of USD 7 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Asemgul's Group

texts.en:
Asemgul M. is the leader of this group. She is thirty-one and married. She has four children: her sons are twelve and eight and her daughters are eleven years old and eleven months. The three elder children are studying in the US and her youngest daughter is at home. Her husband helps her to keep house. 

Asemgul makes felt mat and sells them in Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan). Her neighbor showed her how to make felt mats and five years ago she decided to make money out of them. She started back then with an initial investment of 5000 soms. Now, she makes 15,000 soms each month. With the profits received she bought dishes, carpets, and blankets and significantly improved her family’s nutrition. She is applying to buy materials (wool) for increasing turnover. With the profits received from her business, she is planning to buy cattle and her husband will mainly  raise cattle. This is their plan to increase profits.

Group members: 

Ulukbiubiu Z. is treasurer of the group. She is forty-three and divorced. She has four children: her sons are twenty-four, twenty-one and eighteen and her daughter is seven. She sells convenience goods at her stand. Ten years ago, she started her business selling just drumsticks with an initial investment of 5000 soms. On the profits from selling drumsticks, she was able to buy a stand and increase her assortment. Now, her business brings her in 13,000 soms each month. She is applying for a loan to buy additional convenience goods and increase her assortment and her turnover. Also, with the loan received she is planning to buy a milch cow and sell milk in the mornings. In the future, with the profits from her business she is planning to buy cattle and significantly increase their number.

Shaidylda K. is sixty-three and married. He has four children: his sons are twenty-five and twenty-three and his daughters are thirteen and twelve. His elder son is steelman, his second son is a welder and his daughters are studying in the US. In order to provide for his family, he sells convenience goods at a stand near his house. His children help him in their free time. He started his business after immigration from Tajikistan when they bought a house, a pavilion and goods for resale. Seven years ago, they started their business with an initial investment of 7000 soms and they make 5200 soms each month. He is applying for a loan in order to buy a milch cow. He is planning to sell milk in his convenience pavilion. 

Saipidin S. is forty-one and married. He has three children: his sons are eighteen and five and his daughter is sixteen. He makes felt mats and sells them in Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan). He learned the skills of doing felt mats from his neighbors. His wife helps him in making felt mats making. He started making and selling felt mats four years ago with an initial investment of 5000 soms. Felt mat making brings him in 16,000 soms monthly. For now, with the profits from his business he has been able to buy home appliances and cattle. He is applying for a loan to buy wool to increase his turnover. On the profits from his business, he is planning to expand his business and further increase his turnover. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

loans.use: to purchase wool

loans.name: Graciela De La Asuncion

texts.es:
Graciela vende productos naturales Omnilife desde que se enfermo ella comenzó a utilizarlos y como le ayudo con su salud, compro para venderlos a sus amigas y vecinos. 

Vende productos como el Oni plus, Teatino que son para la buena circulación, trabaja desde muy temprano, aunque no está casada ella continúa trabajando para asegurar su vejez y ayudar económicamente a sus hijos. Cuando se siente cansada deja de venderlo porque caminar le afecta a su salud, una de las dificultades que tienes es la subida momentánea de los precios. 

Ella quiere comprar con el préstamo productos naturales como teatino y star bien para incrementar sus ingresos. En el futuro quiere tener su propio local y asegurar su vejez.
texts.en:
Graciela has sold Omnilife natural products since she became ill and started to used them and they helped her with her health. She buys the products and sells them to her friends and neighbors. She sells products such as "Oni Plus" and "Teatino," which are good for the circulation. She works from the early morning hours, and since she is not married she continues working to save for her old age and to help her children economically. When she feels tired she stops selling, because a lot of walking can affect her health. One of the difficulties she faces is the momentary increase in prices. Graciela wants to use the loan to buy natural products such as "Teatino" and "Star Bien" to increase her earnings. In the future she wants to have her own store and have economic security when she is elderly.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy Omnilife natural producs such as Teatino and Star Bien

loans.name: Liv

texts.en:
Liv L., 36, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. L. sells clothes for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband operates his truck to sell goods everywhere around the province, earning an income of USD 10 per day.

 L. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more goods to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. L. appears in the photograph wearing a black shirt.

loans.name: Marn

texts.en: Marn S., 55, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. loans.name: Lee's Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people make up a village loan, Mrs. Lee C., age 53, is the village bank president, having been selected by its sixteen members. This group is located in Tranh village, Kandal province. Each member will use their portion of their loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Lee C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice for a living. In order to support this farm, she will use the loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice. 

Mrs. Lee C. is a widow with four children: One is a government worker, two are seamstresses in the garment factory, while the other is a student in the local school and also helps the mother on the farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Yorng

texts.en:
Yorng S., 44, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. raises pigs for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a police officer, earning an income of USD 5 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase more piglets to raise for sale.

 In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: buy piglets to raise
